content: Act as a helpful AI assistant

In Julia, You are given a DataFrame `df_cars` with car data with columns `manufacturer` and `model`. Write a function audi_filter that filters down the dataset to only the rows with manufacturer “audi” and model being “a4 or “a4 quattro”, then it should create a new column `audi_a4_type` that equals `true` across all rows. Then return the resulting DataFrame.

Here is a function that filters the `df_cars` dataset to only include rows with manufacturer "audi" and model "a4" or "a4 quattro", then creates a new column `audi_a4_type` that equals `true` across all rows:
```julia
function audi_filter(df::DataFrame)
    df_cars = filter(row -> row.manufacturer == "audi" && (row.model == "a4" || row.model == "a4 quattro"), df)
    df_cars[:, :audi_a4_type] = true
    return df_cars
end
```
You can use this function as follows:
```julia
df_filtered = audi_filter(df_cars)
```
This will create a new DataFrame `df_filtered` that only includes rows with manufacturer "audi" and model "a4" or "a4 quattro", and adds a new column `audi_a4_type` that equals `true` across all rows.
